method.short: Make the selected elements Accordion widgets.
method.name: Accordion

options.name: active
options.desc: Selector for the active element, default is the first child, set to false to display none at start

options.name: header
options.desc: Selector for the header element, eg. div.title, a.head, default is the first child's tagname

options.name: showSpeed
options.desc: Speed for the slideIn, default is 'slow' (for numbers: smaller = faster)

options.name: hideSpeed
options.desc: Speed for the slideOut, default is 'fast' (for numbers: smaller = faster)

options.name: selectedClass
options.desc: Class for active header elements, default is 'selected'

options.name: alwaysOpen
options.desc: Whether there must be one content element open, default is true.

options.name: animated
options.desc: Set to false to disable animations. Default: true

options.name: event
options.desc: The event on which to trigger the accordion, eg. "mouseover". Default: "click"

method.desc:
Make the selected elements Accordion widgets.
Semantic requirements:
If the structure of your container is flat with unique tags for header and content elements, eg. a definition list (dl > dt + dd), you don't have to specify any options at all.
If your structure uses the same elements for header and content or uses some kind of nested structure, you have to specify the header elements, eg. via class, see the second example.
Use activate(Number) to change the active content programmatically.
A change event is triggered everytime the accordion changes. Apart from the event object, all arguments are jQuery objects. Arguments: event, newHeader, oldHeader, newContent, oldContent

examples.desc: Creates an Accordion from the given definition list
Creates an Accordion from the given div structure
Creates an Accordion from the given navigation list
examples.before:
• Header 1
    • Link 1
    • Link 2>
  • Header 2
    • Link 3
    • Link 4>

examples.desc: Updates the element with id status with the text of the selected header every time the accordion changes

method.short: Activate a content part of the Accordion programmatically at the given zero-based index.
method.name: activate
method.desc:
Activate a content part of the Accordion programmatically at the given zero-based index.
If the index is not specified, it defaults to zero, if it is an invalid index, eg. a string, nothing happens.

params.name: index
params.desc: (optional) An Integer specifying the zero-based index of the content to be activated. Default: 0

examples.desc: Activate the second content of the Accordion contained in <div id="accordion">.
Activate the first content of the Accordion contained in <ul id="nav">.

method.short: Override the default settings of the Accordion.
method.name: setDefaults
method.desc: Override the default settings of the Accordion. Affects only following plugin calls.

params.name: options
params.desc: key/value pairs of optional settings, see Accordion() for details

method.author: Jörn Zaefferer (http://bassistance.de)
method.short: Display a customized tooltip instead of the default one for every selected element.
method.name: Tooltip

options.name: delay
options.desc: The number of milliseconds before a tooltip is display, default is 250

options.name: event
options.desc: The event on which the tooltip is displayed, default is "mouseover", "click" works fine, too

options.name: track
options.desc: If true, let the tooltip track the mousemovement, default is false

options.name: showURL
options.desc: If true, shows the href or src attribute within p.url, default is true

options.name: showBody
options.desc:
If specified, uses the String to split the title, displaying the first part in the h3 tag, all following in the p.body tag, separated with
s, default is null

options.name: extraClass
options.desc: If specified, adds the class to the tooltip helper, default is null

options.name: fixPNG
options.desc: If true, fixes transparent PNGs in IE, default is false

method.desc:
Display a customized tooltip instead of the default one for every selected element. The tooltip behaviour mimics the default one, but lets you style the tooltip and specify the delay before displaying it.
In addition, it displays the href value, if it is available.
To style the tooltip, use these selectors in your stylesheet:
#tooltip - The tooltip container
#tooltip h3 - The tooltip title
#tooltip p.body - The tooltip body, shown when using showBody
#tooltip p.url - The tooltip url, shown when using showURL

examples.desc: Shows tooltips for anchors, inputs and images, if they have a title
Shows tooltips for labels with no delay, tracking mousemovement, displaying the tooltip when the label is clicked.

This example starts with modifying the global settings, applying them to all following Tooltips; Afterwards, Tooltips for anchors with class pretty are created with an extra class for the Tooltip: "fancy" for anchors, "fancy-img" for images

method.short: Takes an unordered list and makes all branches collapsable.
method.name: Treeview

options.name: speed
options.desc: Speed of animation, see animate() for details. Default: none, no animation

options.name: collapsed
options.desc: Start with all branches collapsed. Default: none, all expanded

options.name: control
options.desc: Container for a treecontrol, see last example.

options.name: unique
options.desc: Set to allow only one branch on one level to be open (closing siblings which opening). Default: none

options.name: toggle
options.desc: Callback when toggling a branch. Arguments: "this" refers to the UL that was shown or hidden. Works only with speed option set (set speed: 1 to enable callback without animations). Default: none

options.name: store
options.desc: When set, stores the tree-state in a cookie when leaving/reloading the page, and restoring that state when loading the page. By default, no state is stored. Only one tree-per-page can be stored. When specifying the option as a boolean-true, the default setting for cookie-storage is used, saving the state for the browser session. To set a different expiration, set the option to an object with a "expiration" property. Refer to the cookie plugin for details about possible values of that object.

method.desc:
Takes an unordered list and makes all branches collapsable.
The "treeview" class is added if not already present.
To hide branches on first display, mark their li elements with the class "closed". If the "collapsed" option is used, mark intially open branches with class "open".

examples.desc: The following styles are necessary in your stylesheet. There is are alternative sets of images available.
Basic usage example
Create a treeview that starts collapsed. Toggling branches is animated.
Creates a treeview that can be controlled with a few links. Very likely to be changed/improved in future versions.
examples.before: Collapse All Expand All Toggle All

method.short: Defines a standard set of useful validation methods.
method.name: jQuery.validator.methods
method.desc:
Defines a standard set of useful validation methods.
Use jQuery.validator.addMethod() to add your own methods.
If "all kind of text inputs" is mentioned for any if the methods defined here, it refers to input elements of type text, password and file and textareas.

params.name: value
params.desc: The trimmed value of the element, eg. the text of a text input (trimmed: whitespace removed at start and end)

params.name: element
params.desc: the input element itself, to check for content of attributes other then value

params.name: paramater
params.desc: Some parameter, like a number for min/max rules

method.short: Return false if the element is empty.
method.name: jQuery.validator.methods.required
method.desc:
Return false if the element is empty.
Works with all kind of text inputs, selects, checkboxes and radio buttons.
To force a user to select an option from a select box, provide an empty options like <option value="">Choose...</option>

params.name: value
params.desc: The value of the element to check

params.name: param
params.desc: A boolean "true" makes a field always required; An expression (String) is evaluated in the context of the element's form, making the field required only if the expression returns more then one element. The function is executed with the element as it's only argument: If it returns true, the element is required.

examples.desc: Declares an input element that is required.
Declares an input element required, but only if a radio button with id "other" is checked. In other words: As long the "#other" isn't checked, the details field is valid.
Declares an input element "details", required, but only if two other fields are checked.
examples.before: <form id="myform"> <input id="other" type="checkbox" /> <input id="other2" type="checkbox" /> <input name="details" /> </form>

examples.desc: Specifies a group of radio elements. The validation rule is specified only for the first element of the group.
examples.code: <fieldset> <legend>Family</legend> <label for="family_single"> <input type="radio" id="family_single" value="s" name="family" validate="required:true" /> Single </label> <label for="family_married"> <input type="radio" id="family_married" value="m" name="family" /> Married </label> <label for="family_divorced"> <input type="radio" id="family_divorced" value="d" name="family" /> Divorced </label> <label for="family" class="error">Please select your family status.</label> </fieldset>

method.short:
Return false, if the element is
- some kind of text input and its value is too short
- a set of checkboxes has not enough boxes checked
- a select and has not enough options selected
Works with all kind of text inputs, checkboxes and select.
method.name: jQuery.validator.methods.min
method.desc:
Return false, if the element is
- some kind of text input and its value is too short
- a set of checkboxes has not enough boxes checked
- a select and has not enough options selected
Works with all kind of text inputs, checkboxes and select.

examples.desc: Declares an optional input element with at least 5 characters (or none at all).
Declares an input element that must have at least 5 characters.
Specifies a group of checkboxes. To validate, at least two checkboxes must be selected.
examples.code: <fieldset> <legend>Spam</legend> <label for="spam_email"> <input type="checkbox" id="spam_email" value="email" name="spam" validate="required:true,minLength:2" /> Spam via E-Mail </label> <label for="spam_phone"> <input type="checkbox" id="spam_phone" value="phone" name="spam" /> Spam via Phone </label> <label for="spam_mail"> <input type="checkbox" id="spam_mail" value="mail" name="spam" /> Spam via Mail </label> <label for="spam" class="error">Please select at least two types of spam.</label> </fieldset>

method.short:
Return false, if the element is
- some kind of text input and its value is too big
- a set of checkboxes has too many boxes checked
- a select and has too many options selected
Works with all kind of text inputs, checkboxes and selects.
method.name: jQuery.validator.methods.max
method.desc:
Return false, if the element is
- some kind of text input and its value is too big
- a set of checkboxes has too many boxes checked
- a select and has too many options selected
Works with all kind of text inputs, checkboxes and selects.

examples.desc: Declares an input element with at most 5 characters.
Declares an input element that must have at least one and at most 5 characters.

method.short:
Return false, if the element is
- some kind of text input and its value is too short or too long
- a set of checkboxes has not enough or too many boxes checked
- a select and has not enough or too many options selected
Works with all kind of text inputs, checkboxes and selects.
method.name: jQuery.validator.methods.rangeLength
method.desc:
Return false, if the element is
- some kind of text input and its value is too short or too long
- a set of checkboxes has not enough or too many boxes checked
- a select and has not enough or too many options selected
Works with all kind of text inputs, checkboxes and selects.

examples.desc: Declares an optional input element with at least 3 and at most 5 characters (or none at all).
Declares an input element that must have at least 3 and at most 5 characters.
Specifies a select that must have at least two but no more then three options selected.
examples.code: <select id="cars" class="{required:true,rangeLength:[2,3]}" multiple="multiple"> <option value="m_sl">Mercedes SL</option> <option value="o_c">Opel Corsa</option> <option value="vw_p">VW Polo</option> <option value="t_s">Titanic Skoda</option> </select>

method.short: Return true, if the value is greater than or equal to the specified minimum.
method.name: jQuery.validator.methods.minValue
method.desc:
Return true, if the value is greater than or equal to the specified minimum.
Works with all kind of text inputs.

examples.desc: Declares an optional input element whose value must be at least 16 (or none at all).
Declares an input element whose value must be at least 16.

method.short: Return true, if the value is less than or equal to the specified maximum.
method.name: jQuery.validator.methods.maxValue
method.desc:
Return true, if the value is less than or equal to the specified maximum.
Works with all kind of text inputs.

examples.desc: Declares an optional input element whose value must be at most 16 (or none at all).
Declares an input element whose required value must be at most 16.

method.short: Return true, if the value is in the specified range.
method.name: jQuery.validator.methods.rangeValue
method.desc:
Return true, if the value is in the specified range.
Works with all kind of text inputs.

examples.desc: Declares an optional input element whose value must be at least 4 and at most 12 (or none at all).
Declares an input element whose required value must be at least 4 and at most 12.

method.short: Return true, if the value is not a valid email address.
method.name: jQuery.validator.methods.email
method.desc:
Return true, if the value is not a valid email address.
Works with all kind of text inputs.

examples.desc: Declares an optional input element whose value must be a valid email address (or none at all).
Declares an input element whose value must be a valid email address.

method.short: Return true, if the value is a valid url.
method.name: jQuery.validator.methods.url
method.desc:
Return true, if the value is a valid url.
Works with all kind of text inputs.
See http://www.w3.org/Addressing/rfc1738.txt for URL specification.

examples.desc: Declares an optional input element whose value must be a valid URL (or none at all).
Declares an input element whose value must be a valid URL.

method.short: Return true, if the value is a valid date.
method.name: jQuery.validator.methods.date
method.desc:
Return true, if the value is a valid date. Uses JavaScripts built-in Date to test if the date is valid, and is therefore very limited.
Works with all kind of text inputs.

examples.desc: Declares an optional input element whose value must be a valid date (or none at all).
Declares an input element whose value must be a valid date.

method.short: Return true, if the value is a valid date, according to ISO date standard.
method.name: jQuery.validator.methods.date
method.desc:
Return true, if the value is a valid date, according to ISO date standard.
Works with all kind of text inputs.

examples.desc: Declares an optional input element whose value must be a valid ISO date (or none at all).

method.short: Return true, if the value is a valid date.
method.name: jQuery.validator.methods.dateDE
method.desc:
Return true, if the value is a valid date. Supports german dates (29.04.1994 or 1.1.2006). Doesn't make any sanity checks.
Works with all kind of text inputs.

examples.desc: Declares an optional input element whose value must be a valid german date (or none at all).

method.short: Return true, if the value is a valid number.
method.name: jQuery.validator.methods.number
method.desc:
Return true, if the value is a valid number. Checks for international number format, eg. 100,000.59
Works with all kind of text inputs.

examples.desc: Declares an optional input element whose value must be a valid number (or none at all).

method.short: Return true, if the value is a valid number.
method.name: jQuery.validator.methods.numberDE
method.desc:
Return true, if the value is a valid number.
Works with all kind of text inputs.
Checks for german numbers (100.000,59)

examples.desc: Declares an optional input element whose value must be a valid german number (or none at all).

method.short: Returns true if the value contains only digits.
method.name: jQuery.validator.methods.digits
method.desc:
Returns true if the value contains only digits.
Works with all kind of text inputs.

examples.desc: Declares an optional input element whose value must contain only digits (or none at all).

method.short: Returns true if the value has the same value as the element specified by the first parameter.
method.name: jQuery.validator.methods.digits
method.desc:
Returns true if the value has the same value as the element specified by the first parameter.
Keep the expression simple to avoid spaces when using metadata.
Works with all kind of text inputs.

examples.desc: Declares two input elements: The first must contain a valid email address, the second must contain the same adress, enter once more. The paramter is a expression used via jQuery to select the element.

method.short: Validates either a single form on submit or a list of elements on a user-defined event.
method.name: validate

options.name: errorClass
options.desc: Use this class to look for existing error labels and add it to invalid elements. Default: "error"

options.name: wrapper
options.desc: Wrap error labels with the specified element, eg "li". Default: none

options.name: debug
options.desc: If true, the form is not submitted and certain errors are display on the console (requires Firebug or Firebug lite). Default: none

options.name: focusInvalid
options.desc: Focus the last active or first invalid element. Disable for blur-validation, crashes IE otherwise. Default: true

options.name: submitHandler
options.desc: Callback for handling the actual submit when the form is valid. Gets the form as the only argmument. Default: normal form submit

options.name: messages
options.desc: Key/value pairs defining custom messages. Key is the ID or name (for radio/checkbox inputs) of an element, value the message to display for that element. Instead of a plain message another map with specific messages for each rule can be used. Can be specified for one or more elements. Can be overriden by specifying the title attribute on the element. Default: none, the default message for the method is used.

options.name: rules
options.desc: Key/value pairs defining custom rules. Key is the ID or name (for radio/checkbox inputs) of an element, value is an object consisting of rule/parameter pairs, eg. {required: true, min: 3} Default: none, rules are read from metadata via metadata plugin

options.name: event
options.desc: The event on which to validate. If anything is specified, like blur or keyup, each element is validated on that event. Default: none

options.name: onsubmit
options.desc: Validate the form on submit. Set to false to use only other events for validation (option event). Default: true

options.name: meta
options.desc: In case you use metadata for other plugins, too, you want to wrap your validation rules into their own object that can be specified via this option. Default: none

options.name: errorContainer
options.desc: Hide and show this container when validating. Default: none

options.name: errorLabelContainer
options.desc: Search and append error labels to this container, and show and hide it accordingly. Default: none

options.name: showErrors
options.desc: A custom message display handler. Gets the map of errors as the first argument and a refernce to the validator object as the second. You can trigger (in addition to your own messages) the default behaviour by calling the defaultShowErrors() method of the validator. Default: none, uses built-in message disply.

options.name: errorPlacement
options.desc: Used to customize placement of created error labels. First argument: jQuery object containing the created error label Second argument: jQuery object containing the invalid element Default: Places the error label after the invalid element

method.desc:
Validates either a single form on submit or a list of elements on a user-defined event.
The normal behaviour is to validate a form when a submit button is clicked or the user presses enter when an input of that form is focused.
It is also possible to validate each individual element of that form, eg. on blur or keyup.

examples.desc: Validates a form on submit. Rules are read from metadata.
Validates all input elements on blur event (when the element looses focus). Deactivates focus of invalid elements.
Uses form plugin's ajaxSubmit method to handle the form submit, while preventing the default submit.

Validate a form on submit and each element on keyup. Rules are specified for three elements, and a message is customized for the "password" and the "age" elements. Inline rules are ignored. The password is only required when the age is lower then 18. The age is only required when the firstname is blank.

Validates a form on submit. The class used to search, create and display error labels is changed to "invalid". This is also added to invalid elements.
All error labels are displayed inside an unordered list with the ID "messageBox", as specified by the jQuery object passed as errorContainer option. All error elements are wrapped inside an li element, to create a list of messages.
To ease the setup of the form, debug option is set to true, preventing a submit of the form no matter of being valid or not.
Validates a form on submit. Customizes the placement of the generated labels by appending them to the next table cell.

Validates a form on submit. Similar to the above example, but with an additional container for error messages. The elements given as the errorContainer are all shown and hidden when errors occur. But the error labels themselve are added to the element(s) given as errorLabelContainer, here an unordered list. Therefore the error labels are also wrapped into li elements (wrapper option).
examples.before:
The are errors in your form!

    The are errors in your form, see details above!

method.short: Custom expression to filter for blank fields.
method.name: :blank
method.desc: Custom expression to filter for blank fields.

method.short: Custom expression to filter for filled fields.
method.name: :filled
method.desc: Custom expression to filter for filled fields.

method.short: Modify default settings for validation.
method.name: jQuery.validator.setDefaults
method.desc: Modify default settings for validation.

examples.desc: Sets the debug setting for all validation calls following.

method.short: Default messages for all default methods.
method.name: jQuery.validator.messages
method.desc:
Default messages for all default methods.
User addMethod() to add methods with messages.
Replace these messages for localization.

method.type: Boolean True when the form is valid, otherwise false
method.short: Validate on instant the entire form.
method.name: jQuery.validator.protoype.form
method.desc: Validate on instant the entire form.

examples.desc: Triggers form validation programmatcitally.

method.type: Boolean True when the form is valid, otherwise false
method.short: Validate on instant a single element.
method.name: jQuery.validator.protoype.element
method.desc: Validate on instant a single element.

params.name: element
params.desc: A selector or an element to validate

examples.desc: Triggers validation on a single element programmatically.

method.short: Show the specified messages.
method.name: jQuery.validator.protoype.showErrors

params.name: errors
params.desc: One or more key/value pairs of identifiers (IDs or names) and messages

method.desc: Show the specified messages.

examples.desc: Adds and shows error message programmatically.
examples.code: var validator = $("#myform").validate(); validator.showErrors({"firstname": "I know that your firstname is Pete, Pete!"});

method.short: Resets the controlled form, including resetting input fields to their original value (requires form plugin), removing classes indicating invalid elements and hiding error messages.
method.name: jQuery.validator.protoype.resetForm
method.desc: Resets the controlled form, including resetting input fields to their original value (requires form plugin), removing classes indicating invalid elements and hiding error messages.

examples.desc: Reset the form controlled by this validator.

method.short: Add a new validation method.
method.name: jQuery.validator.addMethod
method.desc:
Add a new validation method. It must consist of a name (must be a legal javascript identifier), a function and a default message.
Please note: While the temptation is great to add a regex method that checks it's paramter against the value, it is much cleaner to encapsulate those regular expressions inside their own method. If you need lots of slightly different expressions, try to extract a common parameter.
A library of regular expressions: http://regexlib.com/DisplayPatterns.aspx

params.name: name
params.desc: The name of the method, used to identify and referencing it, must be a valid javascript identifier

params.name: rule
params.desc: The actual method implementation, returning true if an element is valid

params.name: message
params.desc: The default message to display for this method

examples.desc: Adds a method that checks if the value starts with http://mycorporatedomain.com
